title: Give up smoking
tip: If  you're a smoker, quit. It's the single best thing you can do for your heart health.Smoking is one of the main causes of coronary  heart disease. A year after giving up, your risk of a heart attack falls to about half that of a smoker.You're more likely to stop smoking for good if you use NHS stop smoking services. Visit the Smokefree website or ask your GP for help with quitting.

title: Get active
tip: Getting – and staying – active can reduce your risk of developing heart disease. It can also be a great mood booster and stress buster.Do 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity every week. One way to achieve this target is by doing 30 minutes of activity on 5 days a week. Fit it in where you can, such as by cycling to work.

title: Eat more fibre
tip: Eat plenty of fibre to help lower your risk of heart disease – aim for at least 30g a day.Eat fibre from a variety of sources, such as wholemeal bread, bran, oats and wholegrain cereals, potatoes with their skins on, and plenty of fruit and veg.

title: Eat fish
tip: Eat fish at least twice a week, including a portion of oily fish. Fish such as pilchards, sardines and salmon are a source of omega-3 fats, which may help protect against heart disease.Pregnant or breastfeeding women should not have more than 2 portions of oily fish a week.
